metadata.synopsis: In these dialogues, Zevlor reflects on what's happened (an attack of goblins at the gate, which the player helped with) and his mistrust of and bitterness towards the druids who are reluctantly hosting his people. He is exasperated, furious, but also eager to meet anyone who could help. He'll show a flash of anger and frustration at the start if the player struck him, but is pragmatic enough to calm himself once he realises you could be more help to him than harm.

56.speaker: Zevlor
56.text: Forgive that display. Aradin's a blowhard, but that's no cause for me to join him.
56.context: NodeContext: Directly after a confrontation in which he lost his temper with an idiot. Regaining his composure, regretting the outburst.

87.speaker: Zevlor
87.text: Thank you for your help out there. I'm Zevlor.
87.context: NodeContext: Turning his attention to you, formally thanking you for helping them

167.speaker: Zevlor
167.text: And if I'm not mistaken, you're the Blade of Frontiers.
167.context: NodeContext: Paying closer attention to you - you're a famous monster hunter

131.speaker: Zevlor
131.text: Well met, by whatever name. Though I'm afraid that's all the welcome we can give you.
131.context: NodeContext: Accepting your humility, still grateful

3.speaker: Zevlor
3.text: I wouldn't have looked to a drow for help, but I'm grateful all the same. I'm Zevlor.
3.context: NodeContext: Slightly surprised at himself - you're of a species that typically slaughters his kind, but you helped him instead

157.speaker: Zevlor
157.text: Well met. I should warn you - visitors are no longer welcome in this grove.
157.context: NodeContext: Heartfelt greeting, but turning immediately to the bad new he has to give you - this place isn't a safe haven

163.speaker: Zevlor
163.text: A druids' grove, dedicated to the Oak Father, Silvanus. You'll find its keepers just as thorny, I fear.
163.context: NodeContext: Wryly informing you that the locals are not welcoming

130.speaker: Player
130.text: I take my thanks in coin.

54.speaker: Zevlor
54.text: Then you'll have better luck looting the goblins outside - this is a druids' grove.
54.context: NodeContext: Not offered as a serious suggestion, more to underline just how unwelcoming this place is.

172.speaker: Player
172.text: Do you have something against drow?

66.speaker: Zevlor
66.text: I meant no insult. It's simply that yours are a people at war with themselves - I've never known them to care for outsiders.
66.context: NodeContext: Seeking to explain his comment rather than offend

120.speaker: Zevlor
120.text: Aradin didn't make it? Pity - but he might've got more of my people killed, if not for you.

138.speaker: Zevlor
138.text: You acted quickly. I'm just sorry I didn't get there first.

175.speaker: Zevlor
175.context: InternalNodeContext: Remember he could have been KO by Aradin. The flag PostConfrontationDone will make him move after the dialogNodeContext: mrag-RESH-em. Means 'shithead' in infernal. Zevlor has just woken up after being punched in the face by Aradin. He's groggy and pissed off.

8.speaker: Zevlor
8.text: A cheap shot. I should've expected that.
8.context: InternalNodeContext: If NOT drow and NOT Half drow (if player is any of those, the one below will have prio)NodeContext: Disgust in his voice. His idiot enemy clocked him.

126.speaker: Zevlor
126.text: I'll survive a sore jaw. Particularly if it's rid the grove of Aradin.

150.speaker: Zevlor
150.text: True to form, and good riddance. This grove has troubles enough.
150.context: NodeContext: Brushing off Aradin like a bloodsucking fly

34.speaker: Zevlor
34.text: Did I, now? It makes no matter - this grove has problems enough.
34.context: NodeContext: Not interested in the player giving out to him.

2.speaker: Zevlor
2.text: Indeed - I'll survive a sore jaw. This grove has bigger problems right now.

79.speaker: Zevlor
79.text: What I didn't expect was help out there from a drow. Thank you - I'm Zevlor.
79.context: NodeContext: Slightly surprised at himself - you're of a species that typically slaughters his kind, but you helped him instead

22.speaker: Zevlor
22.text: A cheap shot - to be expected from a drow. But you helped us, so instead of killing you, I'll just ask:
22.context: NodeContext: Sneering, barely keeping his temper in check

160.speaker: Zevlor
160.text: I'd ask who you are, but I've heard of the Blade of Frontiers. I'd heard he was a hero, though - not a thug.
160.context: NodeContext: Recognising you from the stories about you, but letting you know that you don't live up to them

28.speaker: Zevlor
28.text: Who in the Nine Hells do you think you are?

124.speaker: Player
124.text: You were heading for bloodshed. I avoided that.

11.speaker: Zevlor
11.text: Very noble of you. Now unless you plan on striking me again, I have other problems to attend to.

6.speaker: Zevlor
6.text: Zevlor. Now unless you plan on striking me again, I have other problems to attend to.

99.speaker: Zevlor
99.text: This place is in enough turmoil. It will be smart for both of us to make allies of enemies.
99.context: NodeContext: Calming himself down - he's willing to let the fight go if you are

17.speaker: Zevlor
17.text: I'll survive a sore jaw. What I won't tolerate is a stranger waltzing in here and interfering in our business.

78.speaker: Zevlor
78.text: Lucky for you, you seem to have spooked that adventurer trash into leaving.

45.speaker: Zevlor
45.text: Whatever your business, I'd see to it quickly - the druids are forcing everyone out.
45.context: NodeContext: Cautionary - his people are also being forced out

37.speaker: Zevlor
37.text: This attack will only strengthen their resolve.

152.speaker: Player
152.text: I have no quarrel with druids.

48.speaker: Player
48.text: Why are they forcing you out?

47.speaker: Zevlor
47.text: There have been several attacks by different monsters. The druids blame us 'outsiders' for drawing them here. Nobody's welcome anymore.
47.context: NodeContext: Explaning a serious situation - the mention of 'outsiders' is bitter - his people always get blamed for everything

51.speaker: Player
51.text: Those goblins - have there been many attacks like that?

179.speaker: Player
179.text: I won't be staying long - I just need to find a healer.

38.speaker: Zevlor
38.text: They've started a ritual to cut the grove off from the world outside.

162.speaker: Zevlor
162.text: We can't stay, but we'll be slaughtered if we leave - we're no fighters.
162.context: NodeContext: Weary, doesn't know what to do

151.speaker: Player
151.text: This ritual - is there no way to convince the druids to stop it?

118.speaker: Zevlor
118.text: I've tried. Kagha - their new First Druid - won't even see me.

75.speaker: Zevlor
75.text: You, though... I know it's not your business, but she owes you for saving this place.
75.context: NodeContext: Slowly and thoughtfully - considering you, idea just occurring to him

77.speaker: Zevlor
77.text: Perhaps you could persuade her. For more time to prepare, if nothing else.

112.speaker: Player
112.text: I'll see what I can do.

83.speaker: Player
83.text: I'm sorry. I've got my own problems.

80.speaker: Player
80.text: I have my own temporal concerns. I need a healer.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: I'll find her. And I'll speak to Kagha while I'm there.

60.speaker: Zevlor
60.text: We'd owe you a great debt. If we're forced to leave now, we won't make it to the city.

159.speaker: Zevlor
159.text: You'll find the druids at the heart of the grove. Please - make them see sense.

108.speaker: Zevlor
108.text: Oh, and if it's of any concern... you're brave to walk around without hiding your heritage. I'll make sure everyone knows that you helped us at the gate.
108.context: NodeContext: Addressing an awkward topic before he forgets - most would run from your race on sight, but he's reassuring us that we're welcome

96.speaker: Zevlor
96.text: You'll find the druids at the heart of the grove. Please - make them see sense, before more lives are lost.

111.speaker: Wyll
111.text: Kagha's a piece of work. Let's see if your wit surpasses your might.

139.speaker: Gale
139.text: I think you should, yes. No harm in trying the diplomatic route.

7.speaker: Shadowheart
7.text: Let's not forget why we're here. No point in wasting precious time on a lost cause.

137.speaker: Lae'zel
137.text: Bah. We've no time to offer aid to every whimpering pup.

119.speaker: Player
119.text: Enough about the ritual. I have my own problems.

52.speaker: Astarion
52.text: Turning your back on the needy to save your own skin? Maybe we'll get along after all.

181.speaker: Zevlor
181.text: I understand. I can only thank you for the help you've already given.
181.context: NodeContext: Disappointed, trying to be understanding

123.speaker: Zevlor
123.text: Just keep your fists to yourself, yes?
123.context: NodeContext: Wry but hint of warning - we started our relationship with this man by punching him in the face. He's cautiously welcoming us.

23.speaker: Zevlor
23.text: We're raised to fear the drow, but you've earned your place here. I'll make sure everyone here knows that.
23.context: NodeContext: Considering us anew - most would run from our race on sight, but he's reassuring us that we're welcome

107.speaker: Zevlor
107.text: If you'll excuse me - I'd best get my people moving.
107.context: NodeContext: Ending conversation, wearily turning back to his business

129.speaker: Wyll
129.text: These poor souls seek a champion - and you turn your back?

178.speaker: Gale
178.text: We've our problems, granted, but there might be some merit in shutting down a local conflict, no?

135.speaker: Shadowheart
135.text: You chose well. We have enough burdens as it is without taking on more.
135.context: CinematicNodeContext: SH is addressing the player rather than Zevlor.NodeContext: Spoken to the player after they decline to help some refugees.

134.speaker: Karlach
134.text: We can't abandon all these people. Right?

158.speaker: Lae'zel
158.text: A rational choice. We mustn't stray from our path.

62.speaker: Player
62.text: What are you offering for my aid?

44.speaker: Zevlor
44.text: We'd owe you a great debt. What little we have, we'll scrape together. It isn't coin we need - it's time.
44.context: NodeContext: Accepting your request for payment for helping him

132.speaker: Zevlor
132.text: You're wounded? The druid Halsin's a renowned healer, but he went with those adventurers. It seems they left him behind.
132.context: NodeContext: Mildly concerned, grows bitter at mention of Aradin/adventurers

84.speaker: Zevlor
84.text: Goblin got you? The druid Halsin's a renowned healer, but he didn't make it back from Aradin's expedition.
84.context: NodeContext: Mildly concerned, grows bitter at mention of Aradin/adventurers

25.speaker: Zevlor
25.text: If it's not too serious, you could try his apprentice, Nettie. She's with the other druids, in the inner grove.
25.context: NodeContext: Thinking, trying to help - but not holding out much hope for your chances

154.speaker: Zevlor
154.text: They've withdrawn there to prepare this damn ritual of theirs.
154.context: NodeContext: Growing bitter at mention of the druid ritual - it's foolishness to him

186.speaker: Zevlor
186.text: We're refugees from Elturel - we took shelter here after gnolls attacked us on the road.

147.speaker: Zevlor
147.text: We were bound for Baldur's Gate, and it was too late to turn back. Elturel had no place for tieflings after the Descent.
147.context: NodeContext: Recounting how his home city turned against his people

12.speaker: Narrator
12.text: *You remember it. Elturel and all its citizens were dragged into Avernus - then back out again.*

100.speaker: Player
100.text: I was there, you know. I'd hoped you'd had a happy ending.

177.speaker: Zevlor
177.text: We got out alive. That's what matters. And you did too, by the looks of things.

156.speaker: Zevlor
156.text: We'll live to tell another tale, if we can just convince these druids not to turn us out on our backsides.

10.speaker: Player
10.text: Let me guess: Your old neighbours called you 'devilkin' and acted like they never knew you.

92.speaker: Zevlor
92.text: How easily such a nasty word slips through the mouth of someone you thought you knew.

41.speaker: Zevlor
41.text: We thought we'd found sanctuary here, but the druids have determined to turn us out.

136.speaker: Karlach
136.text: Gods, these are those tiefs? Their whole city was dragged into Avernus for a while. Zariel was delighted. When they made it back out, I'd hoped they got their happy ending.

169.speaker: Zevlor
169.text: I'm surprised you haven't heard of it.

171.speaker: Zevlor
171.text: The High Overseer - our grand protector - signed a pact with devils. It dragged Elturel straight to Hell.
171.context: NodeContext: Bitter - talking about a traumatic event that disproportianately affected his people

110.speaker: Zevlor
110.text: Lucky for us, a group of adventurers found a way to bring the city back.

94.speaker: Zevlor
94.text: Afterwards, people looked at us and just saw 'devilkin'. No different from the druids here, really.

55.speaker: Narrator
55.text: *'The Descent' - an infernal conspiracy that had seen the entire city of Elturel briefly dragged to the Hells.*

43.speaker: Player
43.text: If your people survived that, they'll survive anything.

63.speaker: Zevlor
63.text: So I hoped. But we've lost so many already - and more will die if we're forced out again.

13.speaker: Player
13.text: Is there a place for tieflings anywhere?

102.speaker: Zevlor
102.text: Hah - a fair point. We can only hope the citizens of Baldur's Gate are more open-minded.

36.speaker: Zevlor
36.text: But we can't get there with those beasts blocking our path.

153.speaker: Player
153.text: Maybe your people should have stayed in Hell.

133.speaker: Karlach
133.context: NodeContext: Player said something rude. She's offended but still hoping they are kidding, so not too aggro

88.speaker: Zevlor
88.text: It seems you're of a mind with our hosts here. But their ritual will force you out, too.
88.context: NodeContext: Suppressing annoyance, pointing out that you're in the same boat

76.speaker: Player
76.text: You made it back from Avernus. Surely you can survive anything?

90.speaker: Player
90.text: Should've stayed in the Hells - our kind might be treated better there.

117.speaker: Player
117.text: That's sad - but it doesn't mean the druids owe you sanctuary.

116.speaker: Zevlor
116.text: Thank you again for your help out there.

5.speaker: Zevlor
5.text: I can see that. You're lucky your little display scared him off.
5.context: NodeContext: Brushing off Aradin like a bloodsucking fly

164.speaker: Zevlor
164.text: Lay hands on me again, however, and every tiefling in this encampment will fall on you like a tide.

121.speaker: Zevlor
121.text: And so will you, if you ever lay hands on me again. That I promise you.
121.context: NodeContext: Not interested in the player giving out to him.
